issues.title: Facing Connection rejected : 400
issues.body:
I'm using windows 10 64-bit machine. This bug was already created and the solution was to use 32 bit executable.

But I don't find 32-bit executable separately now. But I do find a commit  [c910946](https://github.com/Microsoft/IEDiagnosticsAdapter/commit/c9109461161a583dc226566d336bb296534ef421)

It doesn't help as well.

issue_comments.body: I have tried this as well. Not working.

issues.title: Support setScriptSource
issues.body: Long shot, but are there any plans to implement setScriptSource?

issue_comments.body:
Just to be clear, It is currently implemented in Edge? Are the semantics the same as V8's implementation? Any resources with more info on this?

Until then, how about at-least implementing canSetScriptSource to always return false if it is not doing so already.

One of my projects ([amok](http://github.com/caspervonb/amok)) has a feature that spins up a file watcher on script parse and calls setScriptSource whenever the source changes, there's a bit more to it but thats the gist of it.

Now currently only chrome based browsers are supported, but am always looking to support more especially If I don't have to maintain the protocol bridge myself :smile:
Sounds great :+1:
Been a while, any update on this? Edge support is still pending?

issues.title: Disabled CSSproperties do not show up
issues.body: If you disable a property then select a different node that the disabled property was applied to,  nothing will appear because our API to get CSS applied to the node will not find it. Target behavior is showing the property as disabled.

Breakpoints do not work in HTML files
issues.body: Breakpoints within a script tag in an HTML file are never hit.

issue_comments.body: Signing off
Approved
Pull request approved. Thank you for your contribution.

Try the following:
Under Internet options/advanced in Internet Explorer, ensure both "enable enhanced protective mode", and "enable 64 bit tabs for enhanced protective mode" are not checked. Then try using the 32 bit release.

This appears to be caused by IEDiagnosticsAdapter::Poll busy waiting, I'm looking into a fix now. @praveenpuglia I'm guessing your machine has four cores, so one busy thread would result in 25% CPU usage.
Thank you for reporting this issue. It has been fixed by commit b56a4d0.

The x86 version should work if Proxy.dll and IEDiagnosticsAdapter.exe are in the same folder on the desktop, and "enable enhanced protective mode" is disabled in IE options. I would be very surprised if it somehow worked without Proxy.dll. I have not yet tested what happens if they are in a folder with lower permissions, but eventually we should have an installer which will get rid of that problem. Additionally I have verified the issue with the x64 release not working on 64 bit Windows 7, and will be looking into fixing it early next week.
What are you interested in in doing? I'd be happy to explain what I know and help you get started.

The chrome debugging protocol is documented here: https://developer.chrome.com/devtools/docs/protocol/1.1/index 
The short version of how the IEDiagnosticsAdaptor works is we get a command over a web socket from the chrome dev tools, (or any other piece of software that communicates via the chrome debugging protocol). We then have JavaScript running on the page (the IEWebKitImpl project) that receives the command, does appropriate things, and then sends a response back.
To get the styles pane working, I’m guessing that we need to implement DOM.getAttributes
The Basic workflow that I’m using is as follows
1. Debug the chrome dev tools to see how the Chrome dev tools respond to a command.**
2. Implement a handler in JavaScript that is injected onto the page. In this case add a function GetAttributes in Dom.ts that gets the node specified using DOMHandler::_mapUidToNode and reads the relevant properties from the node
3. Format a response that mimics the response chrome gives as closely as possible. Set this on the processedResult object, and then browserHandler.postResponse will send it back to the chrome dev tools.

Hopefully this it helpful for getting you started!

*\* To debug the chrome dev tools with the chrome dev tools, follow these steps
1. Launch chrome from the command prompt with the flag "--remote-debugging-port=9222". For example run “C:\Program Files (x86)\Google\Chrome\Application>chrome --remote-debugging-port=9222”
2. Navigate to a website
3. Open another chrome tab, and navigate to localhost:9222, select the site you navigated to in step 2
4. Hit f12 to debug the chrome dev tools with the chrome dev tools.
5. Under the network inspector, you should see a line that looks like a GUID. Select this to see all of the commands that the dev tools are sending to the page and all of the responses. You may need to refresh the dev tools that are pointed at the page to see network traffic

Update: We have decided that we want to get the core DOM and Console functionality implemented before we go back to working on stability issues. There is no ETA on that but once it is done I will look into this.
Are you running from the released build or building yourself from master? This should be fixed in master, but we have not yet had a release with the fix in it.
This looks like it might be related to issue #9, which I'm working on currently
This should be resolved with commit c910946

Proxy.dll get's injected into the tab that you are debugging. If you only have a single tab open and you try to attach to a process in visual studio you should see two instances of iexplore.exe, one with a name and one with no name. The named one is the internet Explorer frame, and the unnamed one is the tab. If you attach your debugger to the tab process and use the adapter to connect the chrome dev tools to that tab, you should be able to debug the JavaScript from Proxy.dll.

1) There should be two script engines injected onto the page. One with debugger.js and one with most of the rest of the scripts. You should be able to debug both the same way.

2) That seems strange, I've never seen that issue. On Monday I'll try to see if I can figure out what is going on with that.
Signing off.
Before we pull this in we should figure out what third party tools that we want to be compatible with, and try to get a solution that allows all of those cases.

I think Visual Studio can't debug native and script code at the same time, which may be why you are seeing that issue. If it's blocking some work I can look into it more, but otherwise I'm not going to worry about it.
If anyone is interested in contributing to the adapter, this issue would be a good place to start. Feel free to comment here or contact me for assistance.

issue_comments.body:
Thanks for this pull request! :) 

We're going to need you to agree to a contribution license. As the first person for this repro that makes you our guinea pig so this might take a bit longer than usual...

Sincerely appreciate your patience.
@mayuki  could you go ahead and follow the steps at https://cla.microsoft.com/? That should get you setup.
Thanks! :)

We don't have plans to extend this to IE extensions yet or enabling extensions of F12. 

That being said we are keen for the F12 tools to have a HTML/JS extension model that is highly interoperable with Chrome. No plans yet though and we're going to wait for the Project Spartan extensibility model plans before plans for F12 can be made.

No plans.

The adapter itself connects to IE locally only so has to be on the same machine as IE. Which is Windows only. 

That doesn't mean to say that clients of the adapter need to be local always.
Have updated the pull request based on feedback.
Whoops. updated.
Do you have another instance of IEDiagadapter.exe running? Or another app (like chrome) using port 9222?
Thanks all!

Going to merge this for now as it makes sense for API consumers. It does not enable the direct consumption of the Chrome Dev Tools against IE11 via http://<host>:9222 but serving the chrome front end remotely is a diff issue now tracked as #29.
Should be simple to do. I just took a quick stab at it over in the add-JsonVersion branch just need to figure out some fun linker errors - yay.
Unfortunately IE11 doesn't support a mechanism for apply changes against running documents. Such a feature was added to Edge and I'm sure we'll consider it in the future :).

(Didn't mean to close this in such a hurry, sorry!)

The feature, editing a running document, exist in the JavaScript runtime for Edge (Chakra). It's similar to the V8 implementation in that it takes source content and a script id. I'll hunt around on MSDN to find the documentation. It's exposed in a similar manner to all the other diagnostic interfaces for Chakra, which is not at all like a JSON RPC.

Out of curiosity what's the scenario you had in mind? In a question I should have asked earlier.

tl;dr: Yes, the protocol is about the same and it might not be much work to enable it. 

They API surface is roughly the same though there is the odd breaking changes between Edge and IE11.

For the adapter we already ship 64bit versions of the component (proxy.dll) that loads in the tab, as you can still have 64bit tabs in IE11 it's just much, much, less common. 

One example of a significant change is just the permission model as Edge content processes run in an app container which is an even more restricted than LowIL etc. and an ACL has to be added to the DLL to enable it to be loaded into the Edge process. Which actually looks a lot like the 64bit tab problem as 64bit tabs also run in an app container (of a different sort). But that's psychic debugging. 

[Edit: Removing the parts about ICoreWindow enumeration as I need to double check that.]

Right now we're not actively working on this as we believe that the best place for a common API is in the browser itself and this project is a stepping stone for that. This project is always going to be useful for older versions of IE which are no longer being updated. If you do have any suggestions/issues/ideas for the project especially with regards to what scenarios you'd like to, or are, using it for we'd love to hear them.

Specifically, for Edge we don’t have any plans to announce for when this project would become a core part of it. Indeed we might first update this project to fully support Edge as a first step so we can experiment with connecting Edge with different tools without having to rev Edge.

Ah got ya. For what it's worth you do have other options you can make use of now;
If you're on Win10:
1. On Windows 10 you can use F12Chooser.exe in System32\F12\F12Chooser.exe and that will connect to any instance of Edge/IE running in the browser or an app.
2. Visual Studio from VS 2013 onwards can connect to any IE/Edge instance via the attach to process menu and selecting a debug type of "Script". VS also includes the DOM Explorer and Console from F12 so you can make use of those. 

Happy to help you get started with the tools if you'd like. It would be great to know if they are useful in your scenario.

Is the tab process 64 bit? If so you might want to try this step:
`icacls proxy64.dll /grant "ALL APPLICATION PACKAGES":(RX)`
Thanks for the contribution! :)
Not at this time but it's something we could consider as part of the Edge version of the adapter. https://github.com/Microsoft/edge-diagnostics-adapter

Sorry for not replying to this sooner... 

@danazkari the tool only works against IE11 I'm not sure if it would work on IE10, it's not something we have tested...

issue_comments.body: Thanks Dick!
No it should barely use the CPU at all. Are you able to identify steps to reproduce this? Or perhaps get a call stack?
@bedney, can you clarify, do you mean, you'd like to be able to write an extension for IE that could work against IE using the protocol?

This should be fixed by [pull request 6](https://github.com/Microsoft/IEDiagnosticsAdapter/pull/6) but we haven't built a release yet.

It will be a few days -- meantime let me know if this is blocking you? Or possibly you can sync and build for yourself if you have Visual Studio.

Thanks for the report..

Let us know if you get the Chrome tools on OSX connecting to IE (on Windows). Can't think of why it should not work, assuming you can debug Chrome on that same Windows machine (proving the firewall is open)

Is this on Windows 7 only?

I see this also produces the maxed CPU (eg., 50% CPU with 2 cores). 

Alex will debug both issues when he returns on Monday.

Our goal is to make everything work in the DOM explorer, Console, and Debugger that both the Chrome tools and the IE tools support. So that would include the Styles pane. Expect progress this week.

Long term, we'd like to get some of the other tools working, but that's where some of the semantics diverge so it remains to be seen.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master' into BreakMode

Merge pull request #2 from Microsoft/64bit_compat

64bit compat

Adding PDM enabled message queue
- The websocket thread now uses a message queue object to send messages to the browser ui thread
- The message queue uses the PDM to marshal messages on the the UI thread when it is blocked at a breakpoint
- This allows javascript engine running on the ui thread to process messages even while at a breakpoint

Merge pull request #1 from Microsoft/Initial-Demo-Code

Initial demo code

Removing MessageRelay
- Since the messagerelay had no knowledge of the state of the javascript runtime (break/no break) and the debugger needs to process different webkit commands based on that state, we needed to always post to the debugger thread in order to check the message
- This change removes the message relay and makes the debugger thread act as it instead so that it should be able to process all the relevent messages based on the state.
- It can then forward a message to the browser thread when necessary
- Further work is still required to make the browser thread work while the runtime is paused at a breakpoint

    wm.set("123",12);

@danmosemsft - Thanks for the quick reply.

Yes. On Chrome, we leverage this capability by loading a Chrome extension into Chrome and speak the debugging protocol directly to a Chrome task with no server involved. The wireline protocol is the same, but you attach directly to the target. The API is detailed on that page I linked to above.

@andysterland - Thanks for the reply! I can't tell you how cool it is to see Microsoft people on GitHub, collaborating with their developer community! :-)

I understand the desire to wait and see how Spartan might change the extensibility model. If you guys could keep a capability like this in mind when that shakes out, that'd be great. Thanks!
It's not working for me even with x86 version. Same error as in the first comment. Is there another workaround?

For those who is getting 400 error on Window 7, it's important to have `Proxy.dll` placed within the folder where your `IEDiagnosticsAdapter.exe` locates. I was getting 400 error at first, and after downloading and placing `Proxy.dll` there it was gone. 
I would suggest releasing these files in a single ZIP file.

---

*\* Update **

Oops, that was for `v0.1.3 pre-alpha x86`
@praveenpuglia What fixed it for me was moving the `IEDiagnosticsAdapter.exe` to somewhere other than the initial/default "_Downloads_" folder. No `Proxy.dll` needed (Windows 8.1).

Client connection accepted for: /devtools/page/C35B8417-6D4F-4DB6-A9EA-1E85B57F0
1D7 as: 00060320
Perhaps it's something related to using an IP-address based URL?

32-bit w/ Intel(R) Core i7-3615QM CPU @ 2.30GHz
dished out 512MB RAM to the VM

I think the frame error is also disconcerting.
Thanks, praveenpuglia. Using VS 2013 Community does work!

Thanks for the tip, alexcope. Two follow-up questions:
1. I think I can debug the js scripts injected in the browser thread this way. Is there a way to debug the debugger.js that's injected into the debugger thread?
2. It seems to me that once I hit a breakpoint in the cpp code in Proxy or DebuggerCore, then I can no longer debug js scripts. Is there a way to get around that?
Thanks again for your pointers.

Just pitching in here: Why don't make it as available by enabling external connections? 

We as a community, don't know all the tools/solutions yet, and by binding on 0.0.0.0 you don't limit the existing use-cases supported, but expand them.

(said in the context of me awaiting #27 to be fixed)

I just had a look at the source, and it seems like you are starting Chrome with remote debugging enabled in order to serve the front-end, right?

That's strictly not needed, as Chrome has a internal URL which can be used to open DevTools: `chrome-devtools://devtools/bundled/devtools.html?ws=<webSocketUrl>&remoteFrontend=true'`

However the drawback is that it's a "chrome url", which means you can't redirect to it, for security reasons, so the user would have to copy&paste the URL.
Fixed in #27

My C++ isn't the best, but it looks quite good to me :)

https://github.com/Microsoft/IEDiagnosticsAdapter/compare/add-JsonVersion
:+1: Thanks  :bow:!
This could be related to #40
Edge Debugging has been added in a fork of this adaptor. Any future work related to Microsoft Edge will take place here, https://github.com/Microsoft/edge-diagnostics-adaptor
The IE Diagnostics Adapter is deprecated (IE is deprecated), and doesn't support the profiling API's used by Chrome DevTools.

issue_comments.body:
Isn't Edge sharing same protocol?

I mean this tool recognizes Edge tabs perfectly, I can see their titles, URLs etc., and just getting this when actually attempting to connect:

> DEBUG MESSAGE: Attempting to attach to 64 bit tab
> Connection rejected for: /devtools/page/00C668E2-76B5-4EB4-B89F-5C6314DD1F37
> [2015-08-09 20:00:09] [error] Handshake ended with HTTP error: 400

So looks like the problem is just lack of support of 64-bit tabs, but not of Edge in general.
This is a great project. I am doing a lot of work with embedded WebViews and it helps a lot to debug the IE inside a MS Office WebApp for Word.

This is an absolute helpful tool for creating hybrid application.

I use this tool to debug a application running within MS Word (TaskPaneApp), IBM Notes (Webview) and even Outlook. The application itself is something like a cordova hybrid running in different windows applications.

Even if Edge will bring this features itself, will the embedded Webview of Word edge-enabled?
Yes, especially the F12Chooser is really helpful. It would be great, if these tools would be also available for other Windows Versions. A lot of our customers didn't update their OS yet.

Currently you can access the target list "http://<ip>:9222/" remotely, and when you click on a target it redirects to the dev tools at "localhost:9223" which doesn't work. If the client is remote, it would be good to have something saying to use this URL instead (even if you have to copy and paste it).

Ok so it's been quite a few months after last comment on Feb 29th, is there a way to run this in Win10 64bit with current Chrome and IE10? Still getting that same 400 error and default IE dev tools simply doesn't cut it for us....

Please help, this seems like a very promising project.
Looks like the same bug as described here; https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/12112572/
